metadata.subject: Reading
metadata.description: CCSS-aligned reading comprehension assessment with literary and informational texts

questions.text: What color was Sam's ball?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Sam had a red ball. It was his best toy. One day, the ball rolled away. It went under a big bush. Sam was sad. He looked and looked. Then his dog Max came. Max found the ball! Sam was so happy. He gave Max a big hug. "Thank you, Max!" said Sam. They played with the ball all day.
questions.explanation: The text states 'Sam had a red ball.'

questions.text: How did Sam feel when the ball rolled away?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Sam was sad.'

questions.text: What is this story mostly about?

choices: A boy who loses and finds his ball
questionOptions.correctAnswer: A boy who loses and finds his ball

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The main idea is Sam losing his ball and finding it with Max's help.

questions.text: What did Max do to help Sam?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text states 'Max found the ball!'

questions.text: Where did the ball go?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'It went under a big bush.'

questions.text: What do cows give us?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Farms have many animals. Cows live on farms. They give us milk. Chickens live on farms too. They give us eggs. Pigs also live on farms. Farmers take care of all the animals. They feed them every day. They make sure the animals have water. Farmers work very hard. The animals help us get food.
questions.explanation: The text states 'They give us milk.'

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The main topic is farm animals.

questions.text: What do farmers do for the animals?

choices: Feed them and give them water
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Feed them and give them water

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says farmers 'feed them every day' and 'make sure the animals have water.'

questions.text: In this text, what does 'take care of' mean?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Taking care of means looking after and helping.

questions.text: Name two animals that live on farms.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text mentions cows, chickens, and pigs.

questions.text: How did Lily feel during the storm?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Dark clouds came over the house. The wind began to blow. "A storm is coming," said Mom. Lily looked out the window. She saw the trees bend. Rain started to fall. It made a loud sound on the roof. Lily felt a little scared. Mom sat next to her. "Don't worry," Mom said. "We are safe inside." They watched the storm together. Soon the rain stopped. The sun came out. Lily smiled.
questions.explanation: The text says 'Lily felt a little scared.'

questions.text: What did Mom and Lily do during the storm?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'They watched the storm together.'

questions.text: What does 'bend' mean in this story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: When trees bend in wind, they curve and move.

questions.text: What happens at the end of the story?

choices: The sun comes out and Lily smiles
questionOptions.correctAnswer: The sun comes out and Lily smiles

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story ends with 'The sun came out. Lily smiled.'

questions.text: How did Mom help Lily feel better?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: She sat next to her and said they were safe

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Mom comforted Lily by sitting with her and reassuring her.

questions.text: What is the main idea of this text?

choices: Bees and flowers help each other
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Bees and flowers help each other

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Bees are very busy. They fly from flower to flower. Bees drink a sweet juice from flowers. This juice is called nectar. When bees visit flowers, something special happens. Yellow dust sticks to the bee. This dust is called pollen. The bee carries the pollen to other flowers. This helps new flowers grow. Bees and flowers help each other.
questions.explanation: The main idea is how bees and flowers help each other.

questions.text: What is nectar?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Bees drink a sweet juice from flowers. This juice is called nectar.'

questions.text: What sticks to the bee when it visits flowers?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Yellow dust sticks to the bee. This dust is called pollen.'

questions.text: What happens after the bee carries pollen to other flowers?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'This helps new flowers grow.'

questions.text: What do bees drink from flowers?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text states bees drink nectar from flowers.

questions.text: How old was Ana on her birthday?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Today was Ana's birthday. She woke up early. She was very excited. Her family made her favorite breakfast—pancakes with strawberries. After breakfast, Ana's friends came over. They played games in the backyard. Then it was time for cake. The cake had six candles. Ana made a wish and blew them out. Everyone clapped and sang. Ana thought it was the best day ever.
questions.explanation: The cake had six candles, showing Ana turned six.

questions.text: How did Ana feel when she woke up?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'She was very excited.'

questions.text: What happened first in the story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The first event is 'She woke up early.'

questions.text: What is this story mostly about?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The main idea is Ana's birthday celebration.

questions.text: What was Ana's favorite breakfast?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Her family made her favorite breakfast—pancakes with strawberries.'

questions.text: What is this text mostly about?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: You have five senses. Your eyes help you see. You can see colors, shapes, and people. Your ears help you hear. You hear music, voices, and sounds. Your nose helps you smell. Flowers smell sweet. Your tongue helps you taste. You can taste if food is sweet or sour. Your skin helps you feel. You can feel if something is soft or hard. Your five senses help you learn about the world.
questions.explanation: The main topic is the five senses.

questions.text: Which body part helps you smell?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Your nose helps you smell.'

questions.text: How do the five senses help you?

choices: They help you learn about the world
questionOptions.correctAnswer: They help you learn about the world

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Your five senses help you learn about the world.'

questions.text: What does 'sour' mean?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Sour is a sharp, tangy taste, opposite of sweet.

questions.text: Name three of the five senses.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The five senses are seeing, hearing, smelling, tasting, and feeling.

questions.text: How did the tree feel when the boy did not visit?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: There was a big apple tree. A little boy loved the tree. Every day, the boy would climb the tree and eat apples. The tree was happy. The boy grew older. He did not visit as much. The tree felt sad. One day, the boy came back. He was now a man. "I need wood to build a house," he said. The tree gave him branches. "Thank you," said the man. The tree smiled.
questions.explanation: The text says 'The tree felt sad.'

questions.text: What is the lesson of this story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story is about giving and making others happy.

questions.text: What did the man need from the tree?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'I need wood to build a house.'

questions.text: Who is telling this story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: A narrator tells the story, not a character.

questions.text: How did the boy change in the story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: He grew from a little boy into a man

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text shows the boy growing older and becoming a man.

questions.text: Where do polar bears live?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Polar bears live where it is very cold. They live near the North Pole. Polar bears have thick white fur. The fur keeps them warm. They also have a layer of fat under their skin. This fat is called blubber. Blubber helps them stay warm too. Polar bears are good swimmers. They swim in cold water to catch seals. Seals are their favorite food.
questions.explanation: The text says 'They live near the North Pole.'

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?

choices: Polar bears and how they survive
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Polar bears and how they survive

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The main topic is polar bears and their survival adaptations.

questions.text: What is blubber?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'They also have a layer of fat under their skin. This fat is called blubber.'

questions.text: Why do polar bears have thick fur?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'The fur keeps them warm.'

questions.text: What do polar bears like to eat?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Seals are their favorite food.'

questions.text: What color were Mia's mittens?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Mia had two red mittens. She wore them to play in the snow. She made a snowman. She threw snowballs. It was fun! Then Mia looked at her hands. One mitten was gone! "Oh no!" she said. Mia looked everywhere. She looked by the snowman. She looked by the sled. Then she saw something red in the snow. It was her mitten! Mia put it back on her cold hand.
questions.explanation: The text says 'Mia had two red mittens.'

questions.text: What did Mia do before she lost her mitten?

choices: Made a snowman and threw snowballs
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Made a snowman and threw snowballs

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text shows Mia making a snowman and throwing snowballs before losing her mitten.

questions.text: How did Mia feel when she saw her mitten was gone?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Mia said 'Oh no!' showing she was worried.

questions.text: What is the problem in this story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The main problem is that Mia loses her mitten.

questions.text: Where did Mia find her mitten?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Then she saw something red in the snow. It was her mitten!'

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?

choices: Why we have day and night
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Why we have day and night

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: The Earth is always spinning. This gives us day and night. When your side of Earth faces the sun, it is day. The sun gives us light. We can see and play. When your side of Earth turns away from the sun, it is night. The sky gets dark. We see the moon and stars. Day and night happen every day. This pattern never stops.
questions.explanation: The main topic is what causes day and night.

questions.text: What happens when your side of Earth faces the sun?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'When your side of Earth faces the sun, it is day.'

questions.text: What gives us light during the day?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'The sun gives us light.'

questions.text: What does 'spinning' mean?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Spinning means rotating or going around in circles.

questions.text: What do you see in the sky at night?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'We see the moon and stars.'

questions.text: What does Kenji do first in the garden?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Every Saturday, Kenji helps his grandma in her garden. First, they pull the weeds. Weeds are plants that don't belong. Next, they water the flowers. The flowers need water to grow. Then they pick vegetables. Today they picked tomatoes and beans. "You are a good helper," Grandma said. Kenji smiled. He loved spending time with Grandma.
questions.explanation: The text says 'First, they pull the weeds.'

questions.text: What vegetables did they pick?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Today they picked tomatoes and beans.'

questions.text: What are weeds?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Weeds are plants that don't belong.'

questions.text: How does Kenji feel about helping Grandma?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Kenji smiled. He loved spending time with Grandma.'

questions.text: What is this story mostly about?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: Kenji helping his grandma in her garden

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The main idea is Kenji and Grandma working together in the garden.

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Water moves in a circle. This is called the water cycle. First, the sun heats water in lakes and oceans. The water turns into vapor and goes up into the sky. This is called evaporation. High in the sky, the vapor gets cold. It turns into tiny drops. These drops make clouds. When the clouds get full, the drops fall down as rain. The rain fills lakes and oceans again. Then the cycle starts over.
questions.explanation: The main topic is the water cycle.

questions.text: What is evaporation?

choices: When water turns to vapor and goes up
questionOptions.correctAnswer: When water turns to vapor and goes up

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'The water turns into vapor and goes up into the sky. This is called evaporation.'

questions.text: What happens after vapor gets cold in the sky?

choices: It turns into tiny drops and makes clouds
It goes back to the ocean
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It turns into tiny drops and makes clouds

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'It turns into tiny drops. These drops make clouds.'

questions.text: What makes water turn into vapor?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'the sun heats water' causing evaporation.

questions.text: What happens when clouds get full?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'When the clouds get full, the drops fall down as rain.'

questions.text: What is the lesson of this story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Three fish lived in a pond. One day, a boy came to fish. The first fish swam away fast. "I will find a new pond," she said. The second fish hid under a rock. "I will stay very still," he said. The third fish did not move. "Nothing will happen to me," she said. The boy caught the third fish. The first two fish were safe because they were smart.
questions.explanation: The lesson is about being smart to stay safe.

questions.text: What did the first fish do?

choices: Swam away to find a new pond
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Swam away to find a new pond

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'The first fish swam away fast. "I will find a new pond," she said.'

questions.text: Why did the third fish get caught?

choices: She hid in the wrong place
She did not try to get away
questionOptions.correctAnswer: She did not try to get away

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The third fish 'did not move' and said 'Nothing will happen to me.'

questions.text: How are the three fish different?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Each fish makes a different choice about what to do.

questions.text: How did the second fish stay safe?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: He hid under a rock and stayed very still

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says the second fish hid under a rock and stayed still.

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Recycling helps our planet. When you recycle, old things become new things. Paper can be made into new paper. Plastic bottles can become new bottles or even clothes! Cans can be made into new cans. To recycle, put items in the right bin. Paper goes in one bin. Plastic goes in another. Cans go in a metal bin. Recycling is easy. Everyone can help.
questions.explanation: The main topic is recycling.

questions.text: What can plastic bottles become?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Plastic bottles can become new bottles or even clothes!'

questions.text: How is this text organized?

choices: It explains what recycling is and how to do it
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It explains what recycling is and how to do it

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text explains recycling and gives steps to do it.

questions.text: Why did the author write this text?

choices: To explain how to make paper

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author wrote to inform readers about recycling.

questions.text: Name two things that can be recycled.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text mentions paper, plastic bottles, and cans.

questions.text: How did Maya feel at first?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: A new girl came to class. Her name was Maya. She looked nervous. No one talked to her at lunch. Ava saw Maya sitting alone. "Can I sit with you?" Ava asked. Maya smiled and said yes. They talked about their favorite books. They both liked animal stories. "Do you want to play at recess?" asked Maya. "Yes!" said Ava. Now Ava had a new friend.
questions.explanation: The text says 'She looked nervous.'

questions.text: What did Ava and Maya talk about?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'They talked about their favorite books.'

questions.text: What is the message of this story?

choices: Being kind can help you make friends
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Being kind can help you make friends

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story shows how Ava's kindness led to a new friendship.

questions.text: How did Maya change from the beginning to the end?

choices: She went from nervous to happy
She went from happy to sad
She went from loud to quiet
questionOptions.correctAnswer: She went from nervous to happy

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Maya went from looking nervous to smiling and making a friend.

questions.text: What kind of stories do both girls like?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'They both liked animal stories.'

questions.text: What is an amphibian?

choices: An animal that lives only on land
An animal that can live on land and in water
An animal that lives only in water
questionOptions.correctAnswer: An animal that can live on land and in water

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Frogs are amphibians. This means they can live on land and in water. Frogs start life as eggs in the water. The eggs hatch into tadpoles. Tadpoles have tails and live in water. They breathe through gills like fish. As tadpoles grow, they change. They grow legs and lose their tails. Their gills become lungs. Now they are frogs! Adult frogs can hop on land and swim in water.
questions.explanation: The text says 'This means they can live on land and in water.'

questions.text: How is this text organized?

choices: It shows how frogs grow and change
It tells a story about a frog
It lists different kinds of frogs
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It shows how frogs grow and change

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text shows the sequence of how frogs develop.

questions.text: What do tadpoles change into?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text shows tadpoles changing into frogs.

questions.text: How do tadpoles breathe?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'They breathe through gills like fish.'

questions.text: What are two changes that happen when a tadpole becomes a frog?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: They grow legs and lose their tails

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text describes these changes in the transformation.

questions.text: Why did Bear share his honey?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Bear found a pot of honey. "Yum!" he said. He wanted to eat it all. Then he saw Rabbit. Rabbit looked hungry. Bear thought for a moment. "Would you like some honey?" Bear asked. Rabbit's eyes got big. "Really? Thank you!" They shared the honey together. Bear felt happy inside. Sharing made the honey taste even sweeter.
questions.explanation: Bear saw that 'Rabbit looked hungry.'

questions.text: What is the lesson of this story?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The story shows that 'Sharing made the honey taste even sweeter.'

questions.text: What did Bear find?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Bear found a pot of honey.'

questions.text: What does 'felt happy inside' mean?

choices: Bear felt good about what he did
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Bear felt good about what he did

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: It means Bear felt good about sharing.

questions.text: How did Bear change his mind in the story?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: He wanted to eat it all, but then decided to share

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: Bear changed from wanting to eat it all to choosing to share.

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Brushing your teeth keeps them healthy. You should brush twice a day. Brush in the morning and before bed. Here is how to brush: First, put toothpaste on your brush. Use only a little bit. Next, brush the front of your teeth. Move the brush up and down. Then brush the back of your teeth. Don't forget the top! Brush for two minutes. Then rinse and spit. Now your teeth are clean!
questions.explanation: The main topic is how to brush teeth properly.

questions.text: How is this text organized?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text gives step-by-step instructions.

questions.text: How long should you brush your teeth?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Brush for two minutes.'

questions.text: Why did the author write this text?

choices: To teach how to brush teeth
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To teach how to brush teeth

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author wrote to teach proper tooth brushing.

questions.text: When should you brush your teeth?

questionOptions.correctAnswer: In the morning and before bed

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'Brush in the morning and before bed.'

questions.text: Why did the garden need rain?

choices: It was dry and the flowers drooped
questionOptions.correctAnswer: It was dry and the flowers drooped

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: The garden was dry. The flowers drooped. "We need rain," said Grandpa. Tomas looked at the sky. No clouds. The next day, Tomas looked again. Still no clouds. He felt worried about the flowers. On the third day, dark clouds came. Then it started to rain! Tomas and Grandpa danced. The flowers lifted their heads. "The rain came just in time," said Grandpa.
questions.explanation: The text says 'The garden was dry. The flowers drooped.'

questions.text: How did Tomas feel while waiting for rain?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'He felt worried about the flowers.'

questions.text: On which day did it rain?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'On the third day, dark clouds came.'

questions.text: What is this story mostly about?

choices: Waiting for rain to save the garden
questionOptions.correctAnswer: Waiting for rain to save the garden

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The main idea is waiting for rain to help the dry garden.

questions.text: How did Tomas and Grandpa feel when it rained?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: They were happy; the text says 'Tomas and Grandpa danced.'

questions.text: What is this text mainly about?

choices: People who help in our community
questionOptions.correctAnswer: People who help in our community

questions.subject: Reading
questions.passageText: Many people help in our community. Firefighters put out fires. They keep us safe from flames. Police officers help people follow rules. They make sure everyone is safe. Doctors and nurses help sick people get well. They work in hospitals and clinics. Teachers help children learn. They work in schools. Mail carriers bring letters to our homes. All these helpers work together. They make our community a good place to live.
questions.explanation: The main topic is community helpers.

questions.text: Where do doctors and nurses work?
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text says 'They work in hospitals and clinics.'

questions.text: How do community helpers work together?

choices: They all wear the same clothes
They each do different jobs to make the community good
They live in the same place
questionOptions.correctAnswer: They each do different jobs to make the community good

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text shows different helpers doing different jobs to help everyone.

questions.text: Why did the author write this text?

choices: To tell a story about firefighters
To teach about people who help in our community
To explain how to become a doctor
questionOptions.correctAnswer: To teach about people who help in our community

questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The author wrote to inform about community helpers.

questions.text: Name three community helpers from the text.
questions.subject: Reading
questions.explanation: The text mentions several community helpers.
